source.title: Preventing Soil Compaction and Rutting in the Boreal Forest of Western Canada
source.author: Brad J. Sutherland
source.notes: Practical handbook describing field cues, allowable passes, and mitigation steps for medium- and fine-textured soils that approach field capacity.

risk_levels.label: Low risk (firm soils, dry or well frozen)
recommendations: Operate normally but avoid obvious wet depressions and seepage zones.
Re-check conditions whenever slope position, species, or rainfall indicates wetter soil (ADV4N7 Table 3).

risk_levels.label: Some risk (moist soils approaching field capacity)
recommendations: Consult the supervisor about relocating to drier ground or coarser-textured soils.
Reduce machine traffic (â‰¤3 passes) and decrease load size while minimizing turning (ADV4N7 Table 3, p.22).
Schedule skidding within two to three days of falling and limit bunch size when rain weakens soils (p.34).

risk_levels.label: High risk (saturated soils / thawed frost <15 cm)
recommendations: Relocate to drier or frozen ground whenever possible (Tables 3 & 4).
If work must continue, corduroy / slash mat the trail, operate at minimal loads, and plan immediate rehabilitation.
Confine travel to designated trails so only small areas require decompaction once soils strengthen again.
